facts.text: Civil Appeal No. 324 of 1965 was filed.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal No. 324 of 1965. Appeal by special leave

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated August 20, 1963 of Kerala High Court in I.T.R. Case No. 16 of 1962.

anchor.surface_text: from the judgment and order dated August 20,1963, of the Kerala High Court in I.T.R. Case No. 16 of 1962.

facts.text: Appellant is a limited company incorporated under the Travancore Companies Regulation carrying on business in Kerala of manufacturing sugar, running a distillery and tincture factory.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant is a limited companypany incorpora- ted under the Travancore Companies Regulation and is carrying on business, in the State of Kerala,of manufacturing sugar, running a distillery and also a tincture factory.

facts.text: Appellant-company was floated to take over business assets of Travancore Sugars Ltd. which was being wound up and in which State Government held largest shares, Government Distillery at Nagercoil and Government Tincture Factory at Trivandrum.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant-company was floated with a veiw to taking over the business assets of a companypany called Travancore Sugars Ltd.  which was being wound up and in which the State Government held the largest number of shares , the Government Distillery at Nagercoil and the business assets of the Government Tincture Factory at Trivandrum.

facts.text: Agreement dated June 18, 1937 entered between Government of Travancore and Sir William Wright on behalf of Parry Co. Ltd., promoters of appellant-company.

anchor.surface_text: For this purpose an agreement dated June 18, 1937 was entered into between the Government of Travancore and Sir William Wright on behalf of Parry Co. Ltd., the Promoters of the appellant-company.

facts.text: Under Clause 3 of the 1937 agreement, cash consideration for sale of assets of Travancore Sugars Ltd. is 3.25 lakhs rupees.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 3 of the agreement provided that the cash companysideration for the sale of assets of the Travancore Sugars Ltd. shall be 3 .25 lakhs rupees.

facts.text: Under Clause 4(a), cash consideration for Government Distillery arrived at by joint valuation by engineers appointed by parties.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 4 a  provided that the cash companysideration for the sale of the Government Distillery shall be arrived at as a result of joint valuation by the Engineers to be appointed by the parties.

facts.text: Under Clause 5(a), cash consideration for Government Tincture Factory assets is value according to books.

anchor.surface_text: Clause 5 a  stated that the cash companysideration for the sale of assets of the Government Tincture Factory shall be the value according to the books.

facts.text: Under clauses 4(b) and 4(c), Government undertook to recognise transfer of licence from licensees of Distillery to appellant and secure continuance for continuous period of five years after existing licence.

anchor.surface_text: Under cl. 4 b  and  c  of the agreement the Government undertook to recognise the transfer of the licence from the licensees of the Distillery to the appellant and to secure to it the companytinuance of the licence for a companytinuous period of five years after the termination of the then existing licence.

facts.text: Under clause 5(b), Government agreed to purchase pharmaceutical products manufactured by appellant in Tincture Factory for its medical requirements.

anchor.surface_text: Under cl. 5 b  of the agreement the Government agreed to purchase the pharmaceutical products manufactured by the appellant in the Tincture Factory, for its medical requirements.

facts.text: Under clause 7 of 1937 agreement, Government entitled to 20% of net profits per year max Rs 40,000, net profits after depreciation at IT rates and secretaries treasurers remuneration.

anchor.surface_text: cl. 7 of the said agreement provided for futher payments as folows  7 . The Government shall be entitled to twenty per cent of the net profits earned by the companypany in every year subject however to a maximum of Rupees forty thousand per annum, such net profits for the purposes of this clause to be ascertained by deduction of expenditure from gross income and also after- provision has been made for depreciation at number less than the rates of allowances provided for in the income-tax law for the time being in force, and payment of the Secretaries Treasurers remuneration.

facts.text: Agreement dated January 28, 1947 substituted clause 7 to Government entitled to 10% of net profits as assessed to Income-tax in Travancore.

anchor.surface_text: By another agreement dated January 28, 1947 the following clause was substituted for the above cl. 7 of the original agreement The Government shall be entitled to ten per cent of the net profits of the Company in every year. For the purpose of this clause net profits means the amount for which the Companys audited profits in any year are assessed to Income-tax in the State of Travancore.

facts.text: For assessment year 1958-59 (previous year May 1, 1956 to April 30, 1957), amount payable to Government under clause 7 was Rs 42,480.

anchor.surface_text: For the assessment year 1958-59  the companyresponding previous year being May 1, 1956 to April 30, 1957  the amount payable to Government under the aforesaid cl. 7 came to Rs 42,480/-.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed deduction of Rs 42,480 as virtually sharing of profits after they came into existence, relied on Pondicherry Railway Co. v. CIT.

anchor.surface_text: The appellate Assistant Commissioner disallowed the claim of the appellant for deduction of this amount on the ground that it was virtually mere sharing of profits after they came into existence. The appellate Assistant Commissioner relied upon the decision in The Pondicherry-Railway Company C.I.T.

facts.text: Income-tax Appellate Tribunal allowed appellant's appeal, held payment expenditure to earn profits not out of earned profits, relied on British Sugar Manufacturers Ltd. v. Harris.

anchor.surface_text: the appellant preferred an appeal against the order of the appellate Assistant Commissioner to the Income-tax Appellate Tribunal which held that the case came within the principle of the decision in British Sugar and Manufacturers Ltd. v. Harris. Inspector of Taxes 2  and that the payment of company- mission was an expenditure made in order to earn profits of the business and number an expenditure paid out of earned profits.

facts.text: At instance of respondent, Tribunal referred question to Kerala High Court: whether payment of Rs. 42,480 to Travancore Government under agreements dated 18-6-1937 and 28-1-1947 allowable under sec. 10 of Income-tax Act.

anchor.surface_text: At the instance of the respondent the Tribunal referred the following question of law to the High Court of Kerala Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of the case, the payment of Rs. 42,480/- by the assessee to the Travancore Government under the agreements dated  1  5 I.T.C. 363. 58 I.A. 239.  2  1939 I.T.R. 101. 18-6-1937 and 28-1-1947 was allowable under sec. 10 of the Income-tax Act?

facts.text: Kerala High Court by judgment dated August 20, 1963 held payment constituted capital expenditure not allowable under s.10(2)(xv).

anchor.surface_text: By its judgment dated August 20, 1963, the High Court held that the payment of the aforesaid amount companystituted capital expenditure and was number allowable under s.10 2  xv of the Income Tax Act.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeal by special leave from Kerala High Court judgment dated August 20, 1963.

anchor.surface_text: The present appeal is brought, by special leave, from the judgment of the High Court of Kerala dated August 20, 1963.

facts.text: Supreme Court held payment of Rs. 42,480 is revenue expenditure not capital, overruled High Court.

anchor.surface_text: In view of these facts we are of opinion that the payment of the annual sum of Rs. 42,480/ in the present case is number in the nature of capital expenditure but is in the nature of revenue expenditure and the judgment of the High Court of Kerala on this point must be overruled.

facts.text: Consideration for sale of three undertakings: 1. cash in cls. 3,4a,5a; 2. 20% net profits max 40k p.a.

anchor.surface_text: Examining the transaction from this point of view it is clear in the present case that the companysideration for the sale of the three undertakings in favour of the appellant was  1  the cash companysideration mentioned in the principal agreement, viz., cls. 3, 4 a  and 5 a , and  2  the companysideration that Government shall be entitled to twenty per cent of the net profits earned by the appellant in every year subject to a maximum of Rs. 40,000/- per annum.

facts.text: Payment of 20% commission indefinite period, no time limit.

anchor.surface_text: With regard to the second part of companysideration there are three important points to be numbericed. In the first place, the payment of companymission of twenty per cent on the net profits by the appellant in favour of the Government is for an indefinite period and has numberlimitation of time attached to it.

facts.text: Payment related to annual profits from trading, no relation to capital value of assets.

anchor.surface_text: In the second place, the payment of the companymission is related to the annual profits which flow from the trading activities of the appellant-company and the payment has numberrelation to the capital value of the assets.

facts.text: Annual payment not tied to any fixed sum as part of purchase price.

anchor.surface_text: In the third place, the annual payment of 20 per cent companymission every year is number related to or tied up, in any way, to any fixed sum agreed between the parties as part of the purchase price of the three undertakings.

facts.text: Appellant submitted payment not capital but revenue, not part of purchase price, separate considerations provided, in consideration of govt obligations in cls 4b c 5b.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the appellant Mr. Asoke Sen submitted that the payment of Rs. 42,480/- was number capital expenditure but was expenditure of revenue nature which was allowable under s. 10 2   xv  of the Act. It was pointed out that the annual payments under cl. 7 were number part of the purchase price of the assets.Reference was made to cls. 3, 4 a  and 5 a  of the agreement and it was said that separate and full companysiderations were provided for the purchase of the assets of Travancore Sugars Ltd., the Government Distillery and the Government Tincture Factory. In addition to selling these asssets the Government undertook obligations enumerated in cls. 4 b  and  c  and 5 b  already referred to. It was companytended that the appellant agreed to make annual payments to Government in companysideration of these obligations.

facts.text: Respondent contended preamble to 1947 agreement indicates purchase not merely cash but also cl.7 payment.

anchor.surface_text: On behalf of the respondent the opposite view-point was presented and it was said that the preamble to the agreement dated January 28, 1947 indicated that the purchase was number merely for the cash companysideration recited but also for the payment provided by cl. 7. Reference was made to the following portion of the preamble of the agreement dated January, 28, 1947.

holdings.text: the payment of the annual sum of Rs. 42,480/ in the present case is not in the nature of capital expenditure but is in the nature of revenue expenditure and the judgment of the High Court of Kerala on this point must be overruled

anchor.surface_text: In view of these facts we are of opinion that the payment of the annual sum of Rs. 42,480/ in the present case is number in the nature of capital expenditure but is in the nature of revenue expenditure and the judgment of the High Court of Kerala on this point must be overruled.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Transaction viewed commercially: consideration comprised cash payment and indefinite profit-based entitlement; payment characteristics (indefinite period, linked to annual trading profits not capital value, untied to fixed purchase price sum) distinguish from capital instalments; supported by precedents like Commissioners of Inland Revenue v. 36/49 Holdings Ltd. and CIT v. Kolhia Hirdagarh Co. Ltd.; distinguished exceptional cases like Minister of National Revenue v. Catherine Spooner

holdings.text: No single test of universal application can be discovered which may solve every question as to whether a particular outlay by a trader is capital or revenue expenditure; true nature ascertained from agreement covenants in light of surrounding circumstances from commercial viewpoint

anchor.surface_text: It is often difficult, in any particular case, to decide and determine whether a particular expenditure is in the nature of capital expenditure or in the nature of revenue expenditure. It is net easy to distinguish whether an agreement is for the payment of price stipulated in instalments or for making annual payments in the nature of income. The companyrt has to look number only into the documents but also at the surrounding circumstances so as to arrive at a decision as to what was the real nature of the transaction from the companymercial point of view. No single test of universal application can be discovered for a solution of the question.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Restatement of established approach to capital/revenue distinction applied to facts of case

holdings.text: the consideration for the sale of the three undertakings in favour of the appellant was (1) the cash consideration mentioned in the principal agreement, viz., cls. 3, 4(a) and 5(a), and (2) the consideration that Government shall be entitled to twenty per cent of the net profits earned by the appellant in every year subject to a maximum of Rs. 40,000/- per annum

anchor.surface_text: Examining the transaction from this point of view it is clear in the present case that the companysideration for the sale of the three undertakings in favour of the appellant was  1  the cash companysideration mentioned in the principal agreement, viz., cls. 3, 4 a  and 5 a , and  2  the companysideration that Government shall be entitled to twenty per cent of the net profits earned by the appellant in every year subject to a maximum of Rs. 40,000/- per annum.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Derived from textual reading of agreements including preamble to 1947 agreement acknowledging profit entitlement as inter alia consideration

holdings.text: It is not possible to finally determine the appeal as High Court did not deal with other questions; matter remitted to High Court to examine: (1) whether payment tantamount to diversion of profits by paramount title; (2) whether transaction a joint venture for profit sharing; (3) whether requirements of s.10(2)(xv) satisfied

anchor.surface_text: It is number, however, possible for us to finally determine this appeal because the High Court has number dealt with the other questions arising in this reference. Even if the payment of the companymission to the Government by the assessee is number capital but revenue payment, certain other questions arise for companysideration in this case. In the first place, it has to be determined whether the appellant is right in his argument that the payment of the companymission is tantamount to diversion of profits by a paramount title... In the second place, the respondent has companytended that the transaction should be treated as a joint venture with an agreement to share profits between the appellant ,and the Government. In the third place, the High Court has to ,examine whether the requirements of s. 10 2  xv  have been satisfied in this case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: High Court decided only capital/revenue issue without addressing remaining aspects of referred question under s.10

anchor.surface_text: It is number, however, possible for us to finally determine this appeal because the High Court has number dealt with the other questions arising in this reference. Even if the payment of the companymission to the Government by the assessee is number capital but revenue payment, certain other questions arise for companysideration in this case. In the first place, it has to be determined whether the appellant is right in his argument that the payment of the companymission is tantamount to diversion of profits by a paramount title.

anchor.surface_text: It is often difficult, in any particular case, to decide and determine whether a particular expenditure is in the nature of capital expenditure or in the nature of revenue expenditure. It is net easy to distinguish whether an agreement is for the payment of price stipulated in instalments or for making annual payments in the nature of income. The companyrt has to look number only into the documents but also at the surrounding circumstances so as to arrive at a decision as to what was the real nature of the transaction from the companymercial point of view. No single test of universal application can be discovered for a solution of the question.

It is number, however, possible for us to finally determine this appeal because the High Court has number dealt with the other questions arising in this reference. Even if the payment of the companymission to the Government by the assessee is number capital but revenue payment, certain other questions arise for companysideration in this case. In the first place, it has to be determined whether the appellant is right in his argument that the payment of the companymission is tantamount to diversion of profits by a paramount title.
